messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Power Word Problem in Graph Products

Paper Abstract: Abstract The power word problem for a group G𝐺G asks whether an expression u1x1​⋯​unxnsuperscriptsubscript𝑢1subscript𝑥1⋯superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛u_{1}^{x_{1}}\cdots u_{n}^{x_{n}}, where the uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} are words over a finite set of generators of G𝐺G and the xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} binary encoded integers, is equal to the identity of G𝐺G. It is a restriction of the compressed word problem, where the input word is represented by a straight-line program (i.e., an algebraic circuit over G𝐺G). We start by showing some easy results concerning the power word problem. In particular, the power word problem for a group G𝐺G is 𝗎𝖭𝖢1superscript𝗎𝖭𝖢1\mathsf{uNC}^{1}-many-one reducible to the power word problem for a finite-index subgroup of G𝐺G. For our main result, we consider graph products of groups that do not have elements of order two. We show that the power word problem in a fixed such graph product is 𝖠𝖢0superscript𝖠𝖢0\mathsf{AC}^{0}-Turing-reducible to the word problem for the free group F2subscript𝐹2F_{2} and the power word problems of the base groups. Furthermore, we look into the uniform power word problem in a graph product, where the dependence graph and the base groups are part of the input. Given a class of finitely generated groups 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} without order two elements, the uniform power word problem in a graph product can be solved in 𝖠𝖢0​[𝖢=​𝖫UPowWP⁡(𝒞)]superscript𝖠𝖢0delimited-[]subscript𝖢superscript𝖫UPowWP𝒞\mathsf{AC}^{0}[\mathsf{C}_{=}\mathsf{L}^{\operatorname{UPowWP}(\mathcal{C})}], where UPowWP⁡(𝒞)UPowWP𝒞\operatorname{UPowWP}(\mathcal{C}) denotes the uniform power word problem for groups from the class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. As a consequence of our results, the uniform knapsack problem in right-angled Artin groups is 𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯\mathsf{NP}-complete. The present paper is a combination of the two conference papers Lohrey and Weiß (2019b); Stober and Weiß (2022a). In Stober and Weiß (2022a) and previous iterations of this paper our results on graph products were wrongly stated without the additional assumption that the base groups do not have elements of order two. In the present work we correct this mistake. While we strongly conjecture that the result as stated in Stober and Weiß (2022a) is true, our proof relies on this additional assumption.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Arithmetic circuits and counting complexity classes",
        "Relationships among PL, #L, and the determinant",
        "Low-depth uniform threshold circuits and the bit-complexity of straight line programs",
        "Inhomogeneous sorting",
        "Computational Complexity – A Modern Approach",
        "Bounded-width polynomial-size branching programs recognize exactly those languages in NC1",
        "Branch groups",
        "Groups with ALOGTIME-hard word problems and PSPACE-complete compressed word problems",
        "Finite monoids: From word to circuit evaluation",
        "String-Rewriting Systems",
        "The Word Problem",
        "The conjugacy problem in subgroups of right-angled Artin groups",
        "Ueber unendliche diskontinuierliche Gruppen",
        "The Book of Traces",
        "Word equations over graph products",
        "Conjugacy in Baumslag’s Group, Generic Case Complexity, and Division in Power Circuits",
        "Some properties of commutation in free partially commutative monoids",
        "On some equations in free partially commutative monoids",
        "The complexity of knapsack problems in wreath products",
        "Uniqueness theorems for periodic functions",
        "On matrix powering in low dimensions",
        "Knapsack problems for wreath products",
        "The complexity of Grigorchuk groups with application to cryptography",
        "Testing equalities of multiplicative representations in polynomial time (extended abstract)",
        "Graph products of groups",
        "Burnside’s problem on periodic groups",
        "Membership problem for the modular group",
        "Compressed decision problems for graph products and applications to (outer) automorphism groups",
        "Uniform constant-depth threshold circuits for division and iterated multiplication",
        "Word-hyperbolic groups have real-time word problem",
        "Compressed Decision Problems in Hyperbolic Groups",
        "Confluent String Rewriting",
        "The parallel complexity of certain algorithmic problems in group theory",
        "Knapsack and subset sum problems in nilpotent, polycyclic, and co-context-free groups",
        "Evaluation of circuits over nilpotent and polycyclic groups",
        "Logical aspects of Cayley-graphs: the monoid case",
        "Word problems solvable in logspace",
        "Decidability and complexity in automatic monoids",
        "The Compressed Word Problem for Groups",
        "Efficient computation in groups via compression",
        "The submonoid and rational subset membership problems for graph groups",
        "The power word problem",
        "Knapsack in graph groups",
        "Knapsack and the power word problem in solvable Baumslag-Solitar groups",
        "Combinatorics on Words",
        "On a theorem of Marshall Hall",
        "Improved parallel algorithms for generalized baumslag groups",
        "Log-space conjugacy problem in the Grigorchuk group",
        "Knapsack problems in groups",
        "TC0 circuits for algorithmic problems in nilpotent groups",
        "Power circuits, exponential algebra, and time complexity",
        "Self-similar Groups",
        "On the algorithmic unsolvability of the word problem in group theory",
        "Parallel algorithms for group word problems",
        "A Course in the Theory of Groups",
        "The power word problem in graph products",
        "Introduction to Circuit Complexity",
        "The parallel complexity of some constructions in combinatorial group theory",
        "The word problem for free partially commutative groups"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The Power Word Problem in Graph Products, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
